name: Players Evalutation, Bologna La Fotta - EUCF 2024 (4th place)
summary: Players Evaluation based on the main tournament of the season. Measuring the impact of each Player on the Team.
description:
peLaFottaEUCF2024 — Player Evaluation of BFD La Fotta at EUCF 2024

In Ultimate Frisbee, performance isn’t only about goals and assists. A large part of a player’s impact comes from decision-making, defensive pressure, and reliability under stress. Those aspects are usually present in the data, but rarely structured in a way that supports clear evaluation.

peLaFottaEUCF2024 is a player evaluation system built to turn raw match events into a structured, repeatable workflow for measuring individual impact. The project combines custom KPIs with clutch-time analysis to answer a practical question: who is driving outcomes, and under which conditions?

What problem this project solves

Traditional statistics compress too much information into a small number of counters. This project focuses on extracting signal from noisy event data, separating workload from effectiveness, and making performance comparable across players and game contexts.

Workload and involvement

The first step is understanding who is actually involved in play. Possessions played act as a proxy for workload and tactical trust.

Top players by possessions played. This highlights which players consistently handle high volumes of play, independent of scoring output.

Raw workload alone is not enough. The same measure becomes more meaningful when isolated to high-pressure situations.

Top players by possessions played in clutch moments. This shows who is trusted when the margin for error is minimal.

Custom KPIs: measuring impact, not just outcomes

To move beyond surface-level stats, I designed two custom Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) that operate on cleaned and aggregated event data.

  • Scoring Impact — captures contribution to offensive success beyond just goals and assists.
  • Block Creation — highlights defensive impact by accounting for disruption and forced errors, not only recorded blocks.

Together, these metrics allow players to be compared across offensive and defensive dimensions, instead of treating them as separate roles.

Scoring Impact vs Block Creation. This view separates specialists from true two-way contributors.

Clutch-time analysis

Performance stability under pressure is often the difference between winning and losing. The clutch-time analysis isolates possessions played in high-stakes situations to compare how player impact changes when the context becomes unstable.

Clutch-time Scoring Impact vs Block Creation. This highlights players who maintain or improve their effectiveness when pressure increases.

Engineering notes

  • Repeatable pipeline: raw events → cleaning → aggregation → KPI computation → ranking → visualization
  • Metric design: KPIs are designed to be interpretable and decision-oriented, not purely mathematical
  • Separation of concerns: workload, effectiveness, and clutch behavior are treated as distinct dimensions

Making results usable

Outputs are designed to answer concrete questions quickly: who carries workload, who converts it into impact, and who remains reliable when conditions deteriorate.

Scoring Impact ranking (normal vs clutch). Comparing baseline performance to high-pressure situations.

Block Creation ranking (normal vs clutch). Defensive contribution stability under pressure.

Final thoughts

peLaFottaEUCF2024 is not just a sports analytics project. It’s an example of building a structured evaluation system: defining metrics, handling noisy inputs, and producing outputs that can be trusted in real decision-making contexts.

The same approach applies to software systems more broadly: take imperfect inputs, design clear processing steps, and deliver results that people can actually use.

name: Sahel Decision Support — Food Security, Conflict & Displacement (2014–2019)
summary: A decision-support workflow combining food insecurity, conflict and displacement indicators in the Liptako-Gourma region (2014–2019).
description:
Sahel Decision Support — Food Security, Conflict & Displacement (2014–2019)

This project started from a practical constraint: when resources are limited, decisions can’t rely on intuition. You need a way to rank urgency, track trends over time, and explain what’s happening without oversimplifying it.

Sahel Decision Support merges my original work from foodSahel (data visualization and prioritization) and conflictSahel (empirical analysis of the food insecurity–conflict vicious cycle) into a single narrative: turning fragmented datasets into a coherent framework for analysis and communication in the Liptako-Gourma region.

What this project does

  • Integrates multiple open datasets into one analysis-ready pipeline
  • Tracks how food insecurity evolves across provinces from 2014 to 2019
  • Measures relationships between conflict intensity, displacement, and food insecurity
  • Produces visual outputs designed for decision support and clear communication

Why it matters

Food insecurity is rarely a single-variable problem. It moves with conflict, forced displacement, and local instability. The value of this project is not “making charts”, but building a workflow that helps answer: Where is the situation worsening? What correlates with it? Which areas should be prioritized?

Inputs → Processing → Outputs

Inputs

  • Food insecurity indicators (Cadre Harmonisé)
  • Conflict event data and fatalities (ACLED)
  • Internal displacement figures (IOM)
  • Market indicators / food prices (WFP)

Processing

  • Cleaning and harmonizing datasets (time windows, province names, units)
  • Building derived indicators (e.g., conflict severity, province-level summaries)
  • Correlation and trend analysis across multiple dimensions
  • Visualization aimed at non-technical readability

Outputs

  • A consistent, joined dataset ready for analysis
  • Time-series views for high-risk provinces
  • Correlation views showing the food insecurity–conflict–displacement link
  • Maps and plots designed to support prioritization discussions

Technical decisions (engineering highlights)

  • Data harmonization: aligning geographic references and time granularity across sources
  • Quality handling: dealing with missing values, inconsistent naming, and imperfect reporting
  • Reproducibility: analysis structured as a repeatable pipeline (load → clean → compute → visualize)
  • Output design: building visuals meant to be read quickly and interpreted correctly

Geographic focus: the Liptako-Gourma region across Burkina Faso, Mali, and Niger.

Correlation view across key dimensions: insecurity, conflict intensity, and displacement.

Key results

  • The analysis shows a strong relationship between food insecurity, conflict intensity, and internal displacement, reinforcing the idea of a self-perpetuating cycle in the region.
  • Market indicators such as average food prices did not consistently correlate with the other dimensions in this dataset, suggesting the need for deeper feature expansion and local context.
  • The workflow makes it easier to compare provinces over time and communicate trends clearly.

How to run

The project is built in Python and can be executed locally. A typical run looks like this:

  • Install dependencies: pip install -r requirements.txt
  • Run notebooks / scripts: open the notebooks in order (data loading → analysis → plots)
  • Outputs: generated plots and figures used in the reports/presentations

Next steps

  • Expand the market dimension (cereal/livestock prices, household income proxies)
  • Build a lightweight dashboard for periodic updates
  • Test regression/forecasting approaches to move from correlation to prediction

This project represents the kind of work I enjoy: bringing structure to messy data, making tradeoffs explicit, and producing outputs that people can actually use to make decisions.

name: conflictSahel
summary: Assess the food insecurity-conflicts vicious cycle of Liptako-Gourma.
description:
conflictSahel: Understanding the Food Security-Conflict Vicious Cycle

conflictSahel is a data-driven project analyzing the complex relationship between food insecurity, conflict, internal displacement (IDPs), and food prices in the Sahel region, with a specific focus on the Liptako-Gourma area, a cross-border region encompassing Burkina Faso, Mali, and Niger.

Project Scope
This project integrates multiple datasets, to identify patterns and correlations within the food security-conflict dynamic. By leveraging empirical analysis and advanced data visualization, conflictSahel aims to highlight the interplay between these critical dimensions and inform humanitarian interventions.

Key Research Questions
  • What trends have emerged in the three most food-insecure provinces since 2014?
  • How have the dimensions of food security, conflict severity, and displacement evolved?
  • What are the underlying correlations between food insecurity, conflict, and IDP displacement?

Data Sources & Methodology
The project utilizes open-source datasets from the Cadre Harmonisé, World Food Program (WFP), ACLED Project, and International Organization for Migration (IOM). Analytical methods include statistical correlation testing (Pearson’s r), visualization techniques (heatmaps, time series plots), and geographic mapping to reveal spatial and temporal trends.

Findings
Our analysis confirms that food insecurity, conflict size, conflict severity, and IDPs size are strongly correlated, reinforcing the existence of a vicious cycle exacerbating instability in the region. However, average food prices and food price stability showed no significant correlation with the other dimensions, suggesting the need for further exploration.

Correlation Graph between Food Insecurity, Conflict, and IDPs.

Visual Insights
The project's data visualization techniques effectively communicate the severity and progression of crises in the region. Heatmaps, correlation graphs, and time series plots depict how food insecurity and conflicts intertwine over time. Key observations include:

  • All major dimensions (food insecurity, conflict size, and IDP displacement) have worsened since 2016.
  • Menaka’s conflict size showed a decreasing trend starting in 2018, while other provinces remain volatile.
  • The correlation graph confirms the strong link between conflict intensity and forced displacement.

Empirical Analysis of the 3 most Food Insecure provinces in 2019.

Next Steps
Future improvements will focus on:

  • Expanding food price data to include cereal and livestock prices, along with household income statistics.
  • Developing an interactive dashboard that can be updated with real time data to be consulted.
  • Enhancing statistical modeling with regression analysis and predictive forecasting.

Key Takeaways
The food security-conflict vicious cycle in Liptako-Gourma is self-perpetuating, requiring urgent humanitarian intervention. Strengthening resilience strategies is essential to breaking this cycle and stabilizing the region.

Thank you for exploring conflictSahel.

name: foodSahel
summary: Visualization of the Liptako-Gourma food insecurity and its causes in order to asses provinces which are more in need of first aid.
description:
foodSahel: Data-Driven Insights for Food Security in the Sahel

Understanding Food Insecurity Through Data
The foodSahel project is a data-driven initiative designed to assess and visualize food insecurity in the Liptako-Gourma region of the Sahel, an area deeply affected by conflict, economic instability, and climate-related agricultural challenges. By combining multiple data sources, foodSahel uncovers patterns of vulnerability and provides actionable insights for policymakers, humanitarian organizations, and researchers working to mitigate food crises.

Geographical focus of foodSahel: Liptako-Gourma region.

Bridging Data and Decision-Making
At its core, foodSahel translates complex datasets into meaningful stories that highlight the key drivers of food insecurity. Using historical data from 2014 to 2019, the project focuses on identifying:

  • The three most afflicted provinces with the highest percentage of food-insecure people.
  • Key trends over time, assessing how food insecurity has evolved across different provinces.
  • The interplay between food prices, conflict, and displacement, shedding light on the vicious cycle that exacerbates hunger.

Data, Analysis & Visualization
foodSahel integrates multiple dimensions of food security into a cohesive analytical framework:

  • Food Insecurity – Tracking the percentage of people facing food shortages.
  • Food Access & Stability – Analyzing fluctuations in millet prices to gauge economic stress.
  • Conflict Impact – Measuring the number of fatalities and conflict severity (fatalities per conflict).
  • Displacement Crisis – Quantifying the number of Internally Displaced People (IDPs) to assess migration patterns.

Using geospatial analysis, predictive modeling, and data visualization, foodSahel transforms raw statistics into an intuitive narrative of crisis and resilience.

Uncovering links between food insecurity, conflicts, and market prices.

Key Achievements

  • Predictive Modeling for Food Security – Developed models that forecast food shortages by correlating biomass availability, market trends, and conflict data. These insights help anticipate humanitarian needs rather than reacting to them.
  • Data-Driven Geographic Prioritization – By visualizing food insecurity at the province level, foodSahel pinpoints regions where aid is most urgently needed, enabling better resource allocation.
  • Conflict & Food Price Correlation Analysis – Discovered critical relationships between conflict severity, food price spikes, and displacement trends, reinforcing the understanding of food insecurity as a multi-dimensional crisis.

Impact & Future Directions
The insights from foodSahel not only contribute to evidence-based policy decisions but also demonstrate how data storytelling can be a powerful tool in humanitarian efforts. Moving forward, expanding real-time data integration and refining predictive models could further enhance the ability to preempt food crises before they escalate.

With a compelling mix of data science, geospatial analysis, and storytelling, foodSahel turns numbers into action helping to inform strategies that can save lives.
